verses.verse: Moreover <WH5375>, take thou up a lamentation<WH7015> for the princes<WH5387> of Israel<WH3478>,
and say<WH559>, What was thy mother<WH517>? A lioness<WH3833>: she couched<WH7257> among lions<WH738>, in the midst<WH8432> of the young lions<WH3715> she nourished<WH7235> her whelps<WH1482>.
And she brought up<WH5927> one<WH259> of her whelps<WH1482>: he became a young lion<WH3715>, and he learned<WH3925> to catch<WH2963> the prey<WH2964>; he devoured<WH398> men<WH120>.
The nations<WH1471> also heard<WH8085> of him<WH8610>; he was taken in their pit<WH7845>; and they brought<WH935> him with hooks<WH2397> unto the land<WH776> of Egypt<WH4714>.
Now when she saw<WH7200> that she had waited<WH3176>, and her hope<WH8615> was lost<WH6>, then she took<WH3947> another<WH259> of her whelps<WH1482>, and made<WH7760> him a young lion<WH3715>.
And he went up and down<WH1980> among<WH8432> the lions<WH738>; he became a young lion<WH3715>, and he learned<WH3925> to catch<WH2963> the prey<WH2964>; he devoured<WH398> men<WH120>.

And he knew<WH3045> their palaces<WH490>, and laid waste<WH2717> their cities<WH5892>; and the land<WH776> was desolate<WH3456>, and the fulness<WH4393> thereof<WH6963>, because of the noise of his roaring<WH7581>.
Then the nations<WH1471> set<WH5414> against him on every side<WH5439> from the provinces<WH4082>; and they spread<WH6566> their net<WH7568> over him<WH8610>; he was taken in their pit<WH7845>.

And they put<WH5414> him in a cage<WH5474> with hooks<WH2397>, and brought<WH935> him to the king<WH4428> of Babylon<WH894>; they brought<WH935> him into strongholds<WH4685>, that his voice<WH6963> should no more be heard<WH8085> upon the mountains<WH2022> of Israel<WH3478>.
Thy mother<WH517> was like a vine<WH1612>, in thy blood<WH1818>, planted<WH8362> by the waters<WH4325>: it was fruitful<WH6509> and full of branches<WH6058> by reason of many<WH7227> waters<WH4325>.

And it had strong<WH5797> rods<WH4294> for the sceptres<WH7626> of them that bare rule<WH4910>, and their stature<WH6967> was exalted<WH1361> among the thick boughs<WH5688>, and they were seen<WH7200> in their height<WH1363> with the multitude<WH7230> of their branches<WH1808>.

But it was plucked up<WH5428> in fury<WH2534>, it was cast down<WH7993> to the ground<WH776>, and the east<WH6921> wind<WH7307> dried up<WH3001> its fruit<WH6529>: its strong<WH5797> rods<WH4294> were broken<WH6561> off and withered<WH3001>; the fire<WH784> consumed them<WH398>.
And now it is planted<WH8362> in the wilderness<WH4057>, in a dry<WH6723> and thirsty<WH6772> land<WH776>.

And fire<WH784> is gone out<WH3318> of the rods<WH4294> of its branches<WH905>, it hath devoured<WH398> its fruit<WH6529>, so that there is in it no strong<WH5797> rod<WH4294> to be a sceptre<WH7626> to rule<WH4910>. This is a lamentation<WH7015>, and shall be for a lamentation<WH7015>.
